conclusion: To determine the time when objects A and B are farthest apart, we need to analyze the given velocity-time (v-t) graph.
Object A has a linearly increasing velocity.
Object B starts with a decreasing velocity until t1, then increases again.
The distance between the two objects at any time t can be found by calculating the area under the v-t graph for each object up to that time and taking their difference.
Both objects start from the same position, so they are not separated initially at t = 0.
During the interval 0 to t1, the separation between them increases as object A moves faster than object B.
After t1, object B starts accelerating again, but the separation continues to increase as object B's velocity remains less than object A's velocity until some point during this interval.
At t2, the velocities of both objects become equal, and after this point, object B starts moving faster than object A, reducing the separation between them.
The maximum separation occurs just before the velocities of A and B become equal, which happens at t2.
The two objects are farthest apart at time t2.
